description.narrative: By 2022, duty-bearers, including government sector departments, implementing partners and CSOs, have the capacity and systems to deliver equitable, gender-responsive safely managed water and sanitation services, including in schools and in early childhood development centres and health-care facilities, and in emergency situations.,which contributes to Children With Disabilities, Environmental Sustainability, Sanitation, Sanitation (Covid), Water. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, more people in Pakistan, including women and children and the most deprived, stop practicing open defecation and have access to and use safely managed water and sanitation services in rural and deprived urban areas.

participating-org.narrative: CIVIL SOCIETY ORGANIZATION: Community based organization

sector.narrative: WASH in emergencies - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) response including menstrual hygiene management
Water supply - safety/quality/treatment (including household treatment and safe storage)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, duty-bearers, including government sector departments, implementing partners and CSOs, have the capacity and systems to deliver equitable, gender-responsive safely managed water and sanitation services, including in schools and in early childhood development centres and health-care facilities, and in emergency situations.

description.narrative: In 2019, UNICEF support to federal and provincial governments to scale up the Pakistan Approach to Total Sanitation resulted in over 3 million additional people living in open-defecation-free environments. In addition, WASH in Schools, including Menstrual Health and Hygiene (MHM), was incorporated into the National Education Policy and benchmarks for WASH in health facilities are under development. In the districts of Sindh and Balochistan affected by drought-like condition. UNICEF rehabilitated 32 drinking water supply schemes benefitting 387,699 people and 197,000 people in 13 healthcare facilities and 549,425 people in communities received hygiene education. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of people reached with critical WASH supplies (including hygiene items) and services with UNICEF support [COVIDSitRep]
Number of health centres (clinics, hospitals, etc.) equipped with WASH facilities in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support [COVID]
Number of pupils with access to basic WASH service in schools in the reporting year only, with UNICEF direct support

baseline.value: Balochistan : 86% sanitation coverage and 72% water coverage in primary schools in Balochistan. (EMIS Balochistan) FATA: 24% sanitation coverage and 35% water coverage in primary schools in FATA. (WinS Strategy-FATA) KP: 86% sanitation coverage and 72% water coverage in primary schools in KP. (EMIS KP) Punjab: 101150 Sindh: 52% sanitation coverage and 47% water coverage in schools (SEMIS data, 2014-15 )

title.narrative: Number of men and women, girls and boys, who gained access to basic sanitation services in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support

baseline.value: Balochistan =Overall,73% of people have access to improved sanitation, however as per SDGs definition the baseline for safely managed sanitation is zero. FATA = Within FATA, majority of latrines are unimproved pit latrines (51.7%), against the national average of 9% (PSLM 2012-13). However as per SDGs definition the baseline for safely managed sanitation is zero. KP = Overall, 67% of people have access to improved sanitation, however as per SDGs definition the baseline for safely managed sani

title.narrative: Proportion of people with access to a safe drinking water source in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support

baseline.value: Balochistan: 53% population has access to improved water sources that is 43% in rural areas and 81% in urban areas FATA: 31.4% population in FATA uses surface water for drinking purposes, mainly sourced from canals, rivers, springs, ponds and streams. Piped water only accounts for 8.9% households

title.narrative: Number of people living in communities certified free of open defecation in the reporting year only as a result of UNICEF direct support.
